Child marriage takes away a girlâ€™s right to safe and healthy childhood, quality and complete education that can lead to decent economic opportunities, and social and political empowerment. Pakistan has the 6th highest number of girls married before the age of 18 in the world. Child marriage is prevalent due to several reasons including deeply entrenched traditions and customs, poverty, lack of awareness and/or access to education, and lack of security.
The Prohibition of Child Marriage Act was made effective in 2007. This act defines child marriage as a marriage where the groom or the bride are underage, that is, the bride is under 18 years of age or the boy is younger than 21 years.
Parents trying to marry underage girls are subject to action under this law. Since the law makes these marriages illegal, it acts as a major deterrent.

The Prevention of Anti-Women Practices (Criminal Law Amendment) Act, 2011 criminalizes the act of giving women in marriage to settle disputes (Vani) and prevents forced marriages.
This Law (Criminal Law (Third Amendment) Act, 2011) is for prevention of customary practices such as giving a female in marriage or otherwise in badla-e sulh, wanni or swara, depriving women from inheriting property, forced marriages and marriage of females with the Holy Quran.

This Act may be called as Dowry and Bridal Gifts (Restriction) Act, 1976 and is enacted to provide for restriction on dowry and bridal gifts and for matters connected with it. It extends to the whole of Pakistan and applies to all citizens of Pakistan. Under this Act the aggregate value of the dowry and presents given to the bride by her parents and the aggregate value of the bridal gifts or presents given to the bridegroom shall not exceed five thous and rupees. The total expenditure on a marriage, excluding the value of dowry, bridal gifts and presents, but including the expenses on mehndi, baarat and valima, incurred by either party to the marriage shall not exceed two thous and and five hundred rupees. The parents of each party to a marriage shall furnish to the Registrar lists of dowry, bridal gifts and presents given or received in connection with the marriage under Section 8 of this Act. Whoever, contravenes, or fails to comply with, any provision of this Act shall be punished under Section 9. An offence punishable under this Act shall be triable only by a Family Court established under the West Pakistan Family Courts Act, 1964.

To make provision for the protection of women against harassment at the workplace, the Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act, 2010 (Act IV of 2010) was enacted, which was adopted by Punjab vide Punjab Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace (Amendment) Act,2012 (Act III of 2013).
The objective of the said Act is to create a safe working environment for women, which is free of harassment, abuse, and intimidation with a view toward the fulfillment of their right to work with dignity. The Act is also aimed at enabling higher productivity and a better quality of life at work and builds on the principles of equal opportunity for men and women and their right to earn a livelihood without fear of discrimination as stipulated in the Constitution of Pakistan

In Pakistan, maternity benefits for employed women are primarily governed by the West Pakistan Maternity Benefit Ordinance, 1958. Under this ordinance, a woman is entitled to a maternity leave of twelve weeks, dividing it as six weeks before and six weeks after childbirth. During this period, she is to receive her full pay based on her last drawn wages. The law ensures her job security by prohibiting her dismissal during her maternity leave. In cases of miscarriage or medical termination of pregnancy, the ordinance grants her a leave of six weeks with pay, contingent on presenting relevant medical proof. Additionally, if complications or illnesses arise out of pregnancy or delivery, she\'s entitled to an added month of paid leave. While this ordinance sets the national baseline, it\'s essential to recognize that provincial laws in Pakistan might offer additional provisions or modifications concerning maternity benefits.

Fasad-fil-arz, a concept used to decide severity of punishment awarded, including the offender s past convictions, extreme nature of the offence, and the offender being a danger to the community, now includes offences committed in the name of honour. The application of this concept automatically gives rise to severe punishments for honour crimes.
Murder committed in the name of honour is punishable with death or imprisonment for life.
For murder committed in the name of honour, even if the accused is pardoned by the Wali or other family members of the victim, the Court will still punish the accused with imprisonment for life.

The bill on Acid control and Acid Crime recommends 14-year to lifetime imprisonment sentences and levies fines up to Rs1 million for the perpetrators of the crime.
The purpose of the bill is to control the import, production, transportation, hoarding, sale and use of acid to prevent misuse and provide legal support to acid and burn victims.

The Family Courts Act, 1964, in Pakistan is designed to streamline the adjudication of family matters, including marriage, divorce, child custody, and maintenance. Through this act, specialized Family Courts were established to ensure expeditious resolution of family disputes, providing a more focused and efficient avenue for individuals to seek justice in matters of personal and familial importance. This legal mechanism aims to address family-related issues with greater sensitivity and understanding than regular courts.

Legal aid in Pakistan, particularly for women, is encompassed under the Legal Aid and Justice Authority Act, 2020. This act ensures the provision of free legal services to those, especially women, who cannot afford to pay for legal representation or access to the court system. By providing legal advice, representation in court, and other essential services through state-appointed lawyers or authorized legal entities, the act is designed to ensure that every woman, irrespective of her financial situation, can seek justice. The ultimate objective is to guarantee fairness, uphold rights, and provide equal access to justice for all women, emphasizing those from marginalized and vulnerable groups.

The Punjab Protection of Women Against Violence Act, 2016, is a comprehensive legislation in Pakistan\'s Punjab province aimed at providing protection and relief to women facing any form of violence. It encompasses various kinds of abuse, including physical, psychological, sexual, economic, and verbal or emotional harm. The act establishes a system that includes protection centers, shelters, and a toll-free helpline for victims. Moreover, it introduces the concept of \"Protection Officers\" who assist the courts in the timely completion of cases and ensure women receive all entitled rights. This act is a progressive step towards ensuring women\'s safety and providing a structured support system for victims of violence in Punjab.
